p: Important steps in predicting how plants spread across landscapes under climate change are first, quantifying seed dispersal characteristics, and second estimating the survival probability of seeds and seedlings [ 25]. Galapagos tortoises ( Chelonoidis spp.) are prodigious long distance seed dispersers with a mean dispersal distance of 245m [ 26]. On Santa Cruz Island tortoises disperse seeds from at least 64 plant species, of which 27 are introduced species. Some 20% of seeds ingested by tortoises are dispersed > 1 km. Thus, long distance seed dispersal by tortoises is not a rare event and may confer considerable advantages for tortoise-dispersed plant species [ 27, 28].
